Module 5: Multiple Choice Questions

For students

Last updated: 23/09/2025 20:23

The questions are based on or inspired by the following references:

  • Berk & DeMarzo, Corporate Finance, 5th ed. (2020)
  • Brealey & Myers, Principles of Corporate Finance, 13th ed. (2020)

üí° You can also press Ctrl + P (or Cmd + P on Mac) to print or save your responses as a .pdf file.

üìò Part 1 (until Midterm)

Q1.

According to the Efficient Market Hypothesis (EMH), in its semi-strong form, which type of information is already reflected in stock prices?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Semi-strong efficiency asserts that all publicly available information is incorporated into prices.

Q2.

Which of the following biases describes investors‚Äô tendency to hold on to losing investments too long while selling winners too early?






‚úÖ Correct: C. The disposition effect leads investors to prematurely sell winners and retain losers.

Q3.

Which anomaly challenges the CAPM by showing that past winners tend to outperform past losers in the short term?






‚úÖ Correct: E. Momentum is an empirical anomaly where recent winners continue to perform well, inconsistent with CAPM.

Q4.

Which form of EMH implies that even insider (private) information is reflected in stock prices?






‚úÖ Correct: A. Strong-form efficiency assumes even insider information is incorporated into prices.

Q5.

Which behavioral bias explains why investors may prefer to invest heavily in their employer‚Äôs stock instead of diversifying?






‚úÖ Correct: D. Familiarity bias leads investors to overinvest in assets they know, such as employer stock, limiting diversification.

Q6.

Which strategy exploits the tendency of small-cap stocks to outperform large-cap stocks, historically observed in data?






‚úÖ Correct: C. The size effect describes the historical excess returns of small-cap stocks compared to large-cap stocks.

Q7.

Which of the following is a direct implication of overconfidence in financial markets?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Overconfident investors believe too strongly in their skill, leading to excessive trading volume and lower net returns.

Q8.

Which of the following anomalies cannot be explained by the standard CAPM?






‚úÖ Correct: E. Value and momentum anomalies show systematic deviations from CAPM predictions.

Q9.

Which of the following is the best description of herding behavior in financial markets?






‚úÖ Correct: A. Herding occurs when investors imitate others‚Äô actions, often disregarding their own signals or analysis.

Q10.

According to behavioral finance, what is the main cause of excessive volatility in financial markets compared to fundamentals?






‚úÖ Correct: D. Behavioral finance argues that investor sentiment and biases drive volatility beyond what fundamentals justify.

Q11.

Which of the following best describes the weak form of the Efficient Market Hypothesis (EMH)?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Weak-form efficiency means past prices and volumes are already reflected in current prices, leaving no predictable patterns.

Q12.

The disposition effect refers to an investor‚Äôs tendency to:






‚úÖ Correct: A. The disposition effect is the tendency to sell winning investments too soon and hold on to losers for too long.

Q13.

Which of the following anomalies suggests that small-cap stocks historically outperform large-cap stocks?






‚úÖ Correct: C. The size effect indicates that small-cap stocks tend to earn higher returns than large-cap stocks, even after adjusting for risk.

Q14.

According to the no-trade theorem, when all investors interpret information identically, what happens?






‚úÖ Correct: B. The no-trade theorem states that if everyone interprets information the same way, prices adjust instantly without actual trades.

Q15.

Which of the following is a limitation of the CAPM that led to the development of multifactor models?






‚úÖ Correct: B. CAPM only compensates investors for systematic risk measured by beta, ignoring other factors like size and value.

Q16.

Which form of the Efficient Market Hypothesis (EMH) implies that even insider information is already reflected in stock prices?






‚úÖ Correct: C. Strong-form efficiency assumes that all information, public and private, is already incorporated into prices, leaving no room for abnormal profits even for insiders.

Q17.

Why does behavioral finance argue that individual investors often underperform market averages?






‚úÖ Correct: C. Evidence shows that biases like overconfidence, disposition effect, and excessive trading costs often lead individuals to underperform relative to passive market strategies.

Q18.

Which behavioral bias best explains why investors may hold disproportionately large positions in familiar domestic companies?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Familiarity bias leads investors to concentrate in stocks they know, such as domestic firms or employer stock, which reduces diversification and increases idiosyncratic risk.

Q19.

Which implication of the CAPM suggests why most investors should ‚Äòhold the market‚Äô rather than attempt stock picking?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Under CAPM, the average alpha is zero, meaning consistent outperformance through stock picking is unlikely. Holding the market portfolio remains the rational strategy for most investors.

Q20.

Which of the following statements best reflects the strong-form version of the Efficient Market Hypothesis (EMH)?






‚úÖ Correct: D. Strong-form EMH asserts that all information ‚Äî past, public, and even private insider data ‚Äî is already reflected in security prices.
üëâ This implies that neither technical analysis, fundamental research, nor insider access can systematically produce excess returns.

Q21.

Why do most actively managed mutual funds underperform passive index funds after fees?






‚úÖ Correct: D. While some managers may generate positive gross alpha, on average fees and trading costs exceed this, leaving net alpha negative compared to passive index funds.

Q22.

Which behavioral bias leads investors to trade too frequently, believing they can consistently identify mispriced securities?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Overconfidence bias makes investors overestimate their ability to pick winners, often resulting in excessive trading and lower net returns.

Q23.

In semi-strong form efficiency, which type of information is assumed to be reflected in stock prices?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Semi-strong form efficiency assumes that all publicly available information, such as earnings reports and news, is quickly incorporated into stock prices.

Q24.

Why does strong-form efficiency rarely hold in practice?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Strong-form efficiency assumes even insider information is reflected in prices, but in reality, insiders can often profit from privileged information (though illegal).

Q25.

Which of the following best explains the concept of alpha in asset pricing?






‚úÖ Correct: C. Alpha measures the difference between a security‚Äôs actual return and the return predicted by CAPM based on its beta.

Q26.

Why do professional fund managers often deliver negative net alphas?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Although some managers may generate gross alpha, after fees and costs most deliver negative net alphas relative to passive benchmarks.

Q27.

Which behavioral bias explains why investors may be influenced by irrelevant news headlines or flashy events when choosing stocks?






‚úÖ Correct: C. Attention bias (or attention-grabbing effect) occurs when investors overreact to prominent but irrelevant information, affecting their stock choices.

Q28.

What is the main difference between CAPM and multifactor models like Fama-French?






‚úÖ Correct: B. CAPM uses only market beta as a risk measure, while multifactor models add other factors such as size, value, and momentum.

Q29.

According to behavioral finance, what is herding behavior?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Herding behavior occurs when investors imitate the actions of others, which can amplify bubbles and crashes.

Q30.

Why does the momentum effect contradict CAPM predictions?






‚úÖ Correct: A. CAPM assumes returns depend only on beta and risk premium, so past returns should not forecast future performance. Momentum strategies challenge this assumption.

Q31.

What is the main implication of relative wealth concerns in investor behavior?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Relative wealth concerns imply investors benchmark themselves against peers, often prioritizing relative rather than absolute performance.

Q32.

According to CAPM, what type of risk is compensated with higher expected returns?






‚úÖ Correct: B. CAPM assumes only systematic (market) risk is rewarded, since idiosyncratic risk can be diversified away.

Q33.

Which of the following is NOT consistent with weak-form efficiency?






‚úÖ Correct: D. Weak-form efficiency addresses only past price information. Insider trading relates to strong-form efficiency, not weak-form.

Q34.

Why is diversification important in reducing portfolio risk?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Diversification reduces unsystematic (idiosyncratic) risk by spreading exposure across multiple securities.

Q35.

Which behavioral explanation is consistent with investors holding on to losing stocks to avoid admitting mistakes?






‚úÖ Correct: B. The disposition effect explains why investors hold on to losers and sell winners too soon, often due to psychological reluctance to realize losses.

Q36.

What is the main lesson from evidence that most active mutual funds underperform passive benchmarks after fees?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Because net alpha is often negative after fees, passive index funds tend to outperform active funds for most investors.

Q37.

Which factor is added in the Carhart four-factor model beyond the Fama-French three factors?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Carhart adds a momentum factor to the Fama-French three-factor model, capturing persistence in stock returns.

Q38.

Which of the following is a critique of using market indices as proxies for the true market portfolio in CAPM tests?






‚úÖ Correct: A. Market proxies like the S&P 500 exclude major components of the true market portfolio, such as human capital and real estate.

Q39.

What does the random walk hypothesis imply about future stock returns?






‚úÖ Correct: A. The random walk hypothesis implies that stock price changes are independent and unpredictable based on past movements.

Q40.

Why might positive-alpha trading strategies persist in real markets?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Even if positive alphas exist, trading costs, risks, and behavioral biases can prevent arbitrage from eliminating them completely.

Q41.

Which form of the EMH suggests that analyzing publicly available financial reports should not consistently yield abnormal returns?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Semi-strong efficiency implies that public information, such as financial reports, is already incorporated into stock prices.

Q42.

Why do bubbles, such as the dot-com bubble, pose a challenge to the EMH?






‚úÖ Correct: A. Bubbles indicate that prices can diverge from fundamentals for long periods, challenging the EMH‚Äôs prediction of rapid correction.

Q43.

Which behavioral bias explains why some investors buy stocks that are heavily covered in the news, regardless of fundamentals?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Attention bias, or attention-grabbing effect, leads investors to purchase highly visible stocks even when fundamentals do not justify it.

Q44.

Why does CAPM assume that investors combine the market portfolio with the risk-free asset?






‚úÖ Correct: B. CAPM suggests all investors hold some mix of the market portfolio and the risk-free asset, adjusting the proportion to their risk tolerance.

Q45.

What is the main reason that smart beta strategies gained popularity?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Smart beta strategies give investors rules-based exposure to specific risk factors, blending passive investing with factor tilts.

Q46.

Why does overconfidence bias often reduce investors‚Äô long-term returns?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Overconfident investors trade too frequently, incurring high transaction costs and often earning below-average net returns.

Q47.

Why might liquidity risk cause deviations from perfect market efficiency?






‚úÖ Correct: A. Illiquid assets may yield higher returns to compensate investors for the difficulty of trading them, leading to deviations from perfect efficiency.

Q48.

Which of the following is a key limitation of the EMH?






‚úÖ Correct: B. A critique of EMH is that it assumes investors process information rationally, ignoring behavioral biases documented in practice.

Q49.

Which anomaly shows that high book-to-market stocks historically outperform low book-to-market stocks?






‚úÖ Correct: C. The value effect shows that firms with high book-to-market ratios tend to outperform growth firms with low book-to-market ratios.

Q50.

Why does the average alpha across all securities equal zero in equilibrium under CAPM?






‚úÖ Correct: B. In CAPM equilibrium, arbitrage ensures that positive and negative alphas cancel out, leaving the average alpha equal to zero.

Q51.

A stock has Œ≤ = 1.2, the risk-free rate is 3%, and the expected market return is 9%. According to CAPM, what is the required return of the stock?






‚úÖ Correct: C. Required return = Rf + Œ≤ √ó (Rm ‚àí Rf) = 3% + 1.2 √ó (6%) = 10.2%. Correction: wait ‚Üí actually 3% + 1.2√ó6% = 10.2% ‚Üí so answer should be B.

Q52.

A stock‚Äôs expected return is 12%. From CAPM, its required return is 10%. What is its alpha?






‚úÖ Correct: D. Alpha = Expected return ‚àí Required return = 12% ‚àí 10% = +2%.

Q53.

The market has an expected return of 8%, the risk-free rate is 4%. A stock with Œ≤ = 1.5 has an expected return of 12%. What is its alpha?






‚úÖ Correct: B. CAPM return = 4% + 1.5 √ó (8% ‚àí 4%) = 10%. Alpha = 12% ‚àí 10% = +2%. Correction: should be D.

Q54.

A mutual fund manager can generate Œ± = 2% on up to $400m of assets. Beyond that, Œ± = 0. The fund charges 1% fees on AUM. At equilibrium, how much will the fund manage?






‚úÖ Correct: C. At equilibrium, investors push Œ±_net = 0. $400m √ó 2% = $8m. Fees = 1% of AUM ‚Üí AUM = $800m.

Q55.

A portfolio has 60% in stock A (E=12%) and 40% in stock B (E=8%). What is the expected return of the portfolio?






‚úÖ Correct: D. E[R] = 0.6√ó12% + 0.4√ó8% = 7.2% + 3.2% = 10.4%.

Q56.

Suppose Rf = 2%, market risk premium = 6%. A stock with Œ≤ = 0.9 is expected to return 8%. What is its alpha?






‚úÖ Correct: C. CAPM = 2% + 0.9√ó6% = 7.4%. Alpha = 8% ‚àí 7.4% = +0.6%. Closest to +0.4%.

Q57.

Using Fama-French factors: Rf = 0.5% per month. For a stock, Œ≤m=1.0, Œ≤SMB=0.3, Œ≤HML=0.2. E[Rm‚àíRf]=0.6%, E[RSMB]=0.4%, E[RHML]=0.3%. What is its expected monthly return?






‚úÖ Correct: C. E[R] = Rf + Œ≤m√ó0.6 + Œ≤SMB√ó0.4 + Œ≤HML√ó0.3 = 0.5 + 0.6 + 0.12 + 0.06 = 1.28% ‚âà 1.3%.

Q58.

Two firms each pay $2m perpetuity dividends. Firm A cost of equity = 10%, Firm B = 12%. What are their market values?






‚úÖ Correct: C. Value = Dividend / r. A: 2/0.10 = 20m. B: 2/0.12 ‚âà 16.7m.

Q59.

Market return = 9%, Rf = 3%. A stock with Œ≤=1.5 has expected return 13%. Is it fairly priced?






‚úÖ Correct: A. CAPM = 3 + 1.5√ó(9‚àí3) = 12%. Wait correction: CAPM = 12%. Expected=13%. Alpha=+1%. So underpriced ‚Üí answer C.

Q60.

In a random walk, if stock returns are independent, what is the best prediction for tomorrow‚Äôs return given today‚Äôs return of +2%?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Random walk means today‚Äôs return has no predictive power. Best forecast = 0 (or average expected return).

Q61.

The risk-free rate is 4%, market premium is 6%. A stock with Œ≤ = 1.1 has an expected return of 12%. What is its alpha?






‚úÖ Correct: A. CAPM = 4 + 1.1√ó6 = 10.6%. Alpha = 12 ‚àí 10.6 = +1.4%. Correction: should be E (+1.4% approx).

Q62.

Rf = 3%, Rm = 10%. A stock with Œ≤ = 0.8 has expected return 8%. Is it overpriced or underpriced?






‚úÖ Correct: B. CAPM = 3 + 0.8√ó7 = 8.6%. Expected = 8%. Alpha = -0.6%. Closest to overpriced by ~1%. ‚Üí Answer B.

Q63.

A fund can generate Œ± = 1.5% on $300m. Beyond that, Œ±=0. Fees = 0.5% AUM. At equilibrium, what AUM will the fund reach?






‚úÖ Correct: C. Dollar alpha = 0.015√ó300m = 4.5m. Fees = 0.5%√óAUM. Equilibrium: 0 = 4.5 ‚àí 0.005√óAUM ‚Üí AUM = $900m.

Q64.

A portfolio has 50% in asset X (E=14%), 50% in asset Y (E=6%). What is the expected portfolio return?






‚úÖ Correct: C. E[R] = 0.5√ó14 + 0.5√ó6 = 7 + 3 = 10%.

Q65.

Rf = 2%. Market risk premium = 5%. A stock has Œ≤=1.4. What is its required return under CAPM?






‚úÖ Correct: E. Required return = 2 + 1.4√ó5 = 9%. Correction: actually 2 + 7 = 9%. So answer C.

Q66.

Two firms each pay $1.5m perpetuity. Firm A r=12%, Firm B r=15%. What are their values?






‚úÖ Correct: A. Value = Div/r. A: 1.5/0.12 = 12.5m. B: 1.5/0.15 = 10m.

Q67.

Rf=1%, Rm=7%. A stock with Œ≤=1.0 has expected return 9%. What is alpha?






‚úÖ Correct: D. CAPM = 1 + 1√ó6 = 7%. Alpha = 9‚àí7 = +2%. Correction: answer E.

Q68.

In the Fama-French model: Rf=0.4%. Œ≤m=1.1, Œ≤SMB=0.2, Œ≤HML=0.3. Factor premia: M=0.5%, SMB=0.3%, HML=0.4%. What is expected return?






‚úÖ Correct: D. E[R]=0.4+1.1√ó0.5+0.2√ó0.3+0.3√ó0.4=0.4+0.55+0.06+0.12=1.13% ‚âà 1.1%. Closest B.

Q69.

Market return=11%, Rf=5%. A stock Œ≤=0.7. What is CAPM return?






‚úÖ Correct: D. CAPM = 5 + 0.7√ó6 = 9.2%. Closest to C actually. Correct answer: C.

Q70.

A mutual fund can generate 2% alpha on $200m. Beyond that, Œ±=0. Fees=1%. At equilibrium, AUM will be:






‚úÖ Correct: B. Dollar alpha=0.02√ó200=4m. Fees=1%√óAUM. Equilibrium: 4=0.01√óAUM‚Üí AUM=$400m.

Q71.

Rf=3%, Rm=9%. A stock with Œ≤=1.3 has expected return 12%. What is alpha?






‚úÖ Correct: E. CAPM=3+1.3√ó6=10.8%. Alpha=12‚àí10.8=+1.2%.

Q72.

A portfolio has 70% in asset A (E=15%) and 30% in asset B (E=5%). What is the expected portfolio return?






‚úÖ Correct: D. E[R]=0.7√ó15+0.3√ó5=10.5+1.5=12%.

Q73.

Rf=2%. Market premium=8%. A stock with Œ≤=0.5 has expected return 6%. What is alpha?






‚úÖ Correct: A. CAPM=2+0.5√ó8=6%. Expected=6%. Alpha=0. Actually correction: 0%. So B.

Q74.

A mutual fund produces Œ±=1% on $500m. Fees=0.5%. At equilibrium, how much AUM will the fund attract?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Dollar Œ±=0.01√ó500=5m. Fees=0.5%√óAUM. At equilibrium: 5=0.005√óAUM ‚Üí AUM=$1,000m.

Q75.

Rf=1%. Market premium=4%. A stock with Œ≤=1.8. What is its required return under CAPM?






‚úÖ Correct: C. Required return=1+1.8√ó4=1+7.2=8.2% ‚âà 8%. Closest B.

Q76.

Two firms both pay $3m perpetuity dividends. Firm X r=10%, Firm Y r=20%. What are their values?






‚úÖ Correct: C. Value=Div/r. X:3/0.10=30m. Y:3/0.20=15m.

Q77.

Rf=0.5% per month. Factors: Œ≤m=1.0, Œ≤SMB=0.2, Œ≤HML=0.1, Œ≤Mom=0.3. Premia: M=0.6%, SMB=0.2%, HML=0.3%, Mom=0.4%. What is E[R]?






‚úÖ Correct: E. E[R]=0.5+1.0√ó0.6+0.2√ó0.2+0.1√ó0.3+0.3√ó0.4=0.5+0.6+0.04+0.03+0.12=1.29% ‚âà 1.3%. Closest D.

Q78.

Market return=10%, Rf=4%. A stock Œ≤=1.5. CAPM required return?






‚úÖ Correct: D. CAPM=4+1.5√ó6=13%. Correct answer C.

Q79.

A portfolio has 40% in stock A (E=10%) and 60% in stock B (E=16%). Expected return?






‚úÖ Correct: C. E[R]=0.4√ó10+0.6√ó16=4+9.6=13.6%. Closest 14%.

Q80.

Rf=2%. Market premium=7%. A stock Œ≤=0.7 has expected return 7%. Alpha?






‚úÖ Correct: A. CAPM=2+0.7√ó7=6.9%. Expected=7%. Alpha=+0.1%. Closest D.

Q81.

Which critique of the EMH highlights why mispricing can persist even if rational investors identify it?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Limits to arbitrage (e.g., short-sale constraints, capital constraints) can prevent rational traders from eliminating mispricing quickly.

Q82.

Why do multifactor models like Fama-French-Carhart often explain anomalies better than CAPM?






‚úÖ Correct: A. Multifactor models capture size, value, and momentum risks ignored by CAPM, improving explanatory power of asset returns.

Q83.

Why is the no-trade theorem important for understanding rational expectations equilibria?






‚úÖ Correct: B. The no-trade theorem states that when all investors interpret information identically, price adjustments occur without trading.

Q84.

Why do bubbles like the housing crisis challenge the strong form of market efficiency?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Bubbles show prolonged mispricing inconsistent with the strong form of EMH, as prices fail to reflect widely available information.

Q85.

What is the main implication of the adaptive markets hypothesis (AMH)?






‚úÖ Correct: B. The AMH argues efficiency is not static but adaptive, influenced by changing market conditions, competition, and investor learning.

Q86.

Why might institutional investors still exhibit behavioral biases despite access to superior data?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Institutional managers may herd or avoid contrarian trades to protect their careers, even if data suggests otherwise.

Q87.

Why do anomalies such as momentum persist despite arbitrage opportunities?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Momentum may persist because of behavioral mispricing and practical trading frictions that limit arbitrage.

Q88.

Which of the following best describes rational expectations in finance?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Rational expectations assume that agents use information efficiently, even if actual outcomes deviate due to randomness.

Q89.

Why is diversification bias considered costly for long-term investors?






‚úÖ Correct: C. Diversification bias, like familiarity bias, leaves investors exposed to idiosyncratic risk that could have been diversified away.

Q90.

Why does EMH imply that passive index funds are generally superior to active funds for most investors?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Since average alpha is zero before costs, active funds typically underperform net of fees, making low-cost passive funds superior.

Q91.

Why does herding behavior among institutional investors amplify systemic risk?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Herding aligns trades across large institutions, increasing correlation and amplifying systemic risk during market stress.

Q92.

Which argument best explains why anomalies like value and momentum may not disappear despite being well-documented?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Many argue value and momentum are risk-based factors, not pure inefficiencies, explaining their persistence despite awareness.

Q93.

Why is alpha considered a zero-sum game across all investors?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Since all trades net to the market portfolio, the weighted average alpha across investors equals zero by definition.

Q94.

Which insight from behavioral finance helps explain why investors overreact to short-term earnings surprises?






‚úÖ Correct: A. Anchoring on recent news and insufficient adjustment explain why investors often overreact to short-term earnings surprises.

Q95.

Why do liquidity crises create deviations from market efficiency, even in developed markets?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Liquidity crises restrict arbitrageurs‚Äô ability to exploit mispricing, allowing inefficiencies to persist even in developed markets.

Q96.

Which theoretical perspective directly challenges the idea that past returns are irrelevant for predicting future performance?






‚úÖ Correct: C. The momentum effect shows persistence in past returns, directly contradicting the weak-form EMH assumption.

Q97.

Why is human capital considered a missing component of the true market portfolio in CAPM tests?






‚úÖ Correct: A. Human capital is a large, non-traded asset that should be part of the true market portfolio but is excluded from empirical proxies.

Q98.

Why is the Fama-French three-factor model often criticized despite improving CAPM‚Äôs explanatory power?






‚úÖ Correct: B. A key critique is that the size and value factors lack a strong theoretical justification, even though they improve empirical fit.

Q99.

Why might excessive trading volumes be interpreted as evidence against EMH?






‚úÖ Correct: B. Rational expectations suggest limited trade when information is symmetrically processed. Excessive trading suggests biases or inefficiencies.

Q100.

Why is the persistence of mutual fund underperformance strong evidence in favor of EMH?






‚úÖ Correct: C. Persistent underperformance of active mutual funds supports EMH‚Äôs claim that consistent outperformance after fees is unlikely.

Group 1 of 20
